definitions.definition: a fixed or movable upright partition used to divide a room, to give shelter from drafts, heat, or light, or to provide concealment or privacy.
examples: partition, (room) divider he dressed hurriedly behind the screen

definitions.definition: a thing providing concealment or protection.
examples: his jeep was discreetly parked behind a screen of trees
synonyms: windbreak "the hedge acts as a screen against the wind"

definitions.definition: a detachment of troops or ships detailed to cover the movements of the main body.
a partition of carved wood or stone separating the nave of a church from the chancel, choir, or sanctuary.
a frame with fine wire netting used in a window or doorway to keep out mosquitoes and other flying insects.
a part of an electrical or other instrument that protects it or prevents it from causing electromagnetic interference.
a grid placed between the control grid and the anode of a valve to reduce the capacitance between these electrodes.
a flat panel or area on an electronic device such as a television, computer, or smartphone, on which images and data are displayed.
a blank surface on which a movie or photographic image is projected.
movies or television as a medium, genre, or industry.
the data or images displayed on a computer screen.
examples: pressing the F1 key at any time will display a help screen

definitions.definition: a flat piece of ground glass on which the image formed by a camera lens is focused.
a transparent, finely ruled plate or film used in halftone reproduction.
a large sieve or riddle, especially one for sorting substances such as grain or coal into different sizes.
examples: sieve, riddle, strainer, colander, filter sift the dirt through a screen

definitions.definition: conceal, protect, or shelter (someone or something) with a screen or something forming a screen.
examples: her hair swung across to screen her face
synonyms: safeguard "the cottage was screened by the trees"

definitions.definition: separate something from something else with or as if with a screen.
examples: an area had been screened off as a waiting room
synonyms: curtain "the end of the hall had been screened off"

definitions.definition: protect (someone) from something dangerous or unpleasant.
examples: in my country, a man of my rank would be screened completely from any risk of attack

definitions.definition: prevent from causing or protect from electromagnetic interference.
examples: ensure that your microphone leads are properly screened from hum pickup

definitions.definition: show (a movie or video) or broadcast (a television program).
examples: the show is to be screened by HBO later this year
synonyms: put on the air "the program is screened on Thursday evenings"

definitions.definition: test (a person or substance) for the presence or absence of a disease or contaminant.
examples: outpatients were screened for cervical cancer

definitions.definition: check on or investigate (someone), typically to ascertain whether they are suitable for or can be trusted in a particular situation or job.
examples: all prospective presidential candidates would have to be screened by the committee
synonyms: investigate; Moreinformalcheck out "the prospective candidates will have to be screened"check
investigate "all donated blood is screened for the virus"

definitions.definition: evaluate or analyze (something) for its suitability for a particular purpose or application.
examples: only one percent of rain forest plants have been screened for medical use

definitions.definition: exclude someone or something after evaluation or investigation.
examples: anti-spam software can screen out large amounts of unwanted e-mail

definitions.definition: pass (a substance such as grain or coal) through a large sieve or screen, especially so as to sort it into different sizes.
examples: sieve, riddle, sift, strain, filter, winnow coal used to be screened by hand

definitions.definition: project (a photograph or other image) through a transparent ruled plate so as to be able to reproduce it as a halftone.
